com.lonepulse.robozombie.processor
Enum Processors

java.lang.Object
  java.lang.Enum<Processors>
      com.lonepulse.robozombie.processor.Processors
All Implemented Interfaces:
Serializable, Comparable<Processors>
public enum Processors
extends Enum<Processors>

This enum aggregates all thread-safe processor-chains and exposes the services common to each chain and may even offer services which encompass all the chains as a whole. Any swap between chains (e.g. a deprecated implementation for its enhancement) for the same target criteria occurs transparently.

All processor-chains are ensured to be independent of an internal (or an external object's) state and is thread-safe. If a state is incurred, proper ThreadLocal management will be performed.

Since:
1.3.0

Version:
1.1.0

Author:
Lahiru Sahan Jayasinghe

Enum Constant Detail

REQUEST

public static final Processors REQUEST

This is a concrete implementation of AbstractProcessorChain which creates a sequentially executed series of request processors responsible for building the HttpRequest for a request invocation.

This chain consists of the request processors listed below in the given order:

  1. UriProcessor - builds the URI from the endpoint and sub-path and fills @PathParams
  2. HeaderProcessor - populates all static and dynamic HTTP headers
  3. QueryParamProcessor - appends a query-string formulated for any @QueryParams
  4. FormParamProcessor - inserts a form-url-encoded query-string for any @FormParams
  5. EntityProcessor - inserts the HttpEntity identified using @Entity
  6. InterceptionProcessor - runs hooks for custom request processing just before execution

Note that this processor-chain requires a single InvocationContext to be fed into run(Object...)} and returns the HttpRequestBase which was processed by the chain.

Note that a chain-wide failure is NOT recoverable. All failures are of type RequestProcessorException and may be thrown from any arbitrary ProcessorChainLink. Any changes made on the arguments to the chain are NOT rolled back.

Since:
1.3.0

RESPONSE

public static final Processors RESPONSE

This is a concrete implementation of AbstractProcessorChain which creates a sequentially executed series of response processors responsible for handling the HttpResponse which was returned for a request execution.

This chain consists of the response processors listed below in the given order:

  1. HeaderProcessor - retrieves the response headers and makes them available
  2. EntityProcessor - parses and returns the content of the response body

Note that this processor-chain may or may not return the deserialized response entity depending on the availability of response content.

Note that a chain-wide failure is NOT recoverable. All failures are of type ResponseProcessorException and may be thrown from any arbitrary ProcessorChainLink. Any changes made on the arguments to the chain are NOT rolled back.

Since:
1.3.0

run

public Object run(Object... args)

Accepts the arguments which will be used by the processor-chain and invokes the root link which will in-turn invoke all successive links with the arguments and return the final result.

If a chain-wide failure for the current processor-chain is recoverable, ensure that you handle the failure of the appropriate type and take any steps for recovery. For example, a processor chain which acts on the input arguments and yet does not rollback the changes on failure could be mitigated by reverting to a deep-clone of the original arguments.

See AbstractProcessorChain.run(Object...).

Parameters:
args - the arguments to the processor-chain which will be used by the root link and all successive links that follow; see AbstractProcessorChain.onInitiate(ProcessorChainLink, Object...)

Returns:
the final result produced by the tail of the chain which may or may not have been processed for terminal conditions by AbstractProcessorChain.onTerminate(Object, Object...); ensure that you cast this to the type which is expected from the processor-chain

Throws:
InvocationException - if a chain-wide failure occurred in either the request or response processor chains

Since:
1.3.0
